slidelink.displaytext: Main Components of Noise Risk Assessment
State of Hearing & Degree of Hearing Loss

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Noise & Hearing Conservation Awareness

Click START to begin.

This is the navigation guide.

You can click Script tab to read the narration.

Click here to view the Abbreviations, Glossary and References.

Hi! Welcome to Noise and Hearing Conservation Awareness eLearning.

This eLearning is intended to create awareness on noise, its effects to health, as well as how to control noise at the workplace.

By the end of this module, you should be able to:

•define noise and its effects to health

•explain the importance of noise control and hearing conservation

•describe the probable high noise areas and the action to control noise exposure at workplace

Once you’ve completed the module, there will be a quiz consisting of 10 questions. The pass percentage is 80% and above.

Are you ready? Let’s start the eLearning journey!

Here are the contents of this module.

Click the NEXT button to proceed.

Before we learn further about noise, let’s learn about sound.

Sound is pressure variation in air, water or some other medium that can be detected by the human ear.

There are two components of sound. One of the components is frequency.

Frequency is the rate of sound pressure variation per second emitted from its source.

It is also known as Pitch measured in unit ‘Hertz’.

Let’s compare these two graphs.

Graph B has greater number of cycles per second than graph A. Therefore, B has higher frequency than A.

Another component of sound is amplitude.

It is also equivalent to loudness and intensity.

Amplitude is the amount of sound pressure measured in the unit of Decibel (dB).

Let’s compare these two graphs, B has the higher intensity than A, which indicates that the sound produced for B is louder than A.

This diagram shows the typical sound levels generated by different sources available in our environment.

A very loud or moderate loud sound if exposed frequently over a long period of time can cause harm to the human ear.

Based on the research done, it is believed that hearing damage is possible to occur at 85 decibels if exposed for long period.

Both occupational and non-occupational exposure to excessive noise may cause adverse health effects in a long run.

Non-occupational includes listening to music using a headphone at high volume and exposure to gun shot from hunting activities.

Have you ever wondered how we hear?

This diagram shows the cross section of a human ear.


It is divided into three parts: the outer, middle and inner ear.

Any sound wave produced by vibration are captured through the pinna. The waves then travel through ear canal.

The waves hit the eardrum and cause it to vibrate. This vibration will trigger ossicles bones in the middle of the ear to vibrate.

The vibrations from ossicles are transmitted to the fluid in the cochlea. Pressure will be exerted on the fluid which will cause the hair cells inside the cochlea to bend.

The sound wave from cochlea is transferred into the auditory nerve to generate impulse. Finally, generated impulse is sent to the brain which is then interpreted as sound.

Prolonged exposure to loud sounds either during work or outside work can destroy the hair cells and they might stop functioning forever.

You have learned about sound. Now, let’s learn about noise!

The sound is so loud and irritating!

Did you know that noise is any unwanted sound that may adversely affect the health and well-being of individuals or populations?

Everyday, we are exposed to different levels of noise which may potentially harm our hearing.

How do we know when it is too noisy?

You are in a noisy area when:

•you have to shout to be heard when the other individual is within an arm's length

•you feel discomfort in the ears

•you feel a ringing sensation in the ears or head after a single or a period of exposure and

•noise warning signs are posted

There are 4 types of noise, which are Steady State, Fluctuating, Impulsive and Intermittent.

Steady State can be either Continuous or Non-Continuous noise. Its sound level has negligibly small fluctuation of less than 3 decibels at all or most of the time.

Fluctuating noise is a variation of noise level whose intensity rises or falls by more than 3 decibels.

Impulsive noise is a short burst of loud noise that lasts for less than 1 second.

Intermittent noise can be either Steady or Fluctuating. Its sound level suddenly drops to the ambient level several times over a period of observation.

Click on the PLUS buttons to learn more.

What would happen if we are exposed to excessive noise over a long period of time?

It will affect our health on both, Auditory or Ear Damage and Non-Auditory.

Auditory or Ear Damage is an effect where people start to lose their hearing from a high frequency of 4000 hertz and moving slowly to conversation frequency in range between 500 to 3000 hertz.

The effects can be Temporary Threshold Shift, Permanent Standard Threshold Shift, Tinnitus and Noise Induced Hearing loss.

Non-Auditory is an effect caused by hearing loss which can reduce the quality of life which includes annoyance and stress, disruption in concentration disturbance while sleeping or relaxing and eventually leading to serious fatigue.

It also leads to wrong information being relayed due to disruption of communication.

Realising the adverse effects of noise, it is important for the Company to implement a Hearing Conservation Programme or HCP at the workplace.

HCP is a set of carefully planned activities carried out with the aim of protecting and maintaining the hearing of employees.

The purpose of HCP is to minimise the risk associated with excessive noise exposure and to prevent Occupational Noise Related Hearing Disorders.

Components of this programme shall include identification of excessive noise, Noise Risk Assessment, noise control, Audiometric Testing, information, instruction and training, as well as record keeping.

Further explanation on the components of HCP will be covered in the subsequent lessons.

OK, now it is time to refresh what we have learned so far.

Look at these 2 graphs, which of the graph will produced louder sound?

Select the correct statement and click SUBMIT.

An employer shall comply to Noise Exposure Limits (NELs) as outlined in Malaysian regulations and Company requirements.

The employer shall ensure that none of the employees are exposed to:

•daily noise exposure level (average for 8 hours) not exceeding 85dB(A)

•maximum sound pressure level not exceeding 115dB(A) at any time

•peak sound pressure level not exceeding 140dB(C)

In addition, the Noise Exposure Limits can be inferred based on duration limits as specified in this table. For example, if someone is exposed to average noise level of 88 decibels, the maximum allowable duration of exposure is 4 hours.

Please take note that in locations where more stringent statutory requirements or Company contractual agreement are available, the more stringent requirements shall take precedence.

If exposed to excessive noise exceeding NELs, the employer shall take such measures to reduce the excessive noise.

Compliance to NELs shall be demonstrated through Noise Risk Assessment, which we will learn in the next lesson.

Noise Risk Assessment is aimed to evaluate noise risks that may impact employees’ health.

The employer needs to identify whether the employees may be exposed to excessive noise in the workplace on yearly basis.

Upon identification, the employer shall appoint a competent Noise Risk Assessor (NRA) to conduct a Noise Risk Assessment.

This assessment includes determining noise source, assessing personal noise exposures, noise mapping & noise risk evaluation.

It shall be reviewed every 5 years or when directed by the authority.

The employer shall keep a copy of the report of the Noise Risk Assessment at or near the workplace.

Noise Risk Assessment consists of Area Monitoring and Personal Monitoring.

Area Monitoring

Area Monitoring is conducted by having an initial walk around the work areas to identify noise sources, excessive noise areas, noise type and levels.

Sound Level Meter (SLM) is used in this monitoring.

The output of this measurement includes identification of noise sources and development of Noise Map.

Any area that might be exposed to excessive noise exceeding the NEL, shall be identified as “Hearing Protection Zone” and identified by an appropriate warning signs.

Click the tab to learn about Personal Monitoring.

Personal Monitoring

Personal Monitoring is carried out after proper selection of employees who are working in excessive noise areas, according to similar exposure group.

The monitoring shall be taken throughout the selected employees’ work shift.

The purpose of Personal Monitoring is to evaluate employees’ exposure to noise during their work shift.

They should be asked not to temper with the microphone or the dosimeter and to work as normal.

The tool used for this monitoring is Noise Dosimeter.

The output of the Personal Monitoring is noise exposure levels of the monitored employee that will be compared against NELs and determined if further controls are needed.

How can we control the noise at our workplace?

In general, noise can be controlled either at source, at path or at receiver.

Noise at the source can be controlled by Elimination, Substitution and Engineering Control.

Engineering Control can also be demonstrated to control noise at the path.

At the receiver, noise can be controlled by Administrative Control and Personal Hearing Protector (PHP).

All these controls are placed in the Hierarchy of Noise Control according to their effectiveness on reducing noise exposure.

These controls must be applied to reduce the noise risks so far as practicable, considering factors such as practicality to the work or process, availability of technology and reasonable cost.

Elimination requires all sources that can produce excessive noise to be removed if feasible. This can also be achieved through implementation of low noise purchasing policy.

Another noise control is Substitution. This control requires replacement of noisy equipment with a less noisy equipment.

The other 3 controls will be discussed over the next few pages.

Next control is Engineering Control.

It can be done by modifying the equipment or its surrounding physical structure to reduce mechanical or aerodynamic noise.

Here are some examples of the application of Engineering Controls at the workplace.

Both employer and employee play a big and important role in complying with rules and regulations related to noise exposure, in order to ensure safe working conditions.

In Malaysia, a fine not exceeding RM10,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 1 year or BOTH can be imposed if employer is found to be violating regulatory requirements on noise.

Click on each role to learn more on their responsibilities.

In addition to the Engineering Control, Administrative Control also needs to be put in place to reduce noise exposure to employees.

Here are some examples of Administrative Control:

•Job rotation to reduce duration of exposure to noise

•Keep employees a good distance away from noise sources

•Supervision in ensuring the use of PHP by the employees at the hearing protection zone

•Employee exposed to excessive noise to undergo information & training programme on a yearly basis

•Any area where a person may be exposed to excessive noise exceeding the limit shall be marked with ‘Hearing Protection Zone’, demarcated & identified by an appropriate warning sign

The last noise control in the hierarchy is Personal Hearing Protector or PHP.

PHP can be used when there are no other controls practicable or can be used as supplementary control, along with other existing controls.

PHP can be categorised into two types namely Earplugs and Earmuffs.

Click PLUS buttons to find out their advantages and disadvantages.

To choose the correct PHP, we need to consider the following factors:

•the characteristics of the noise

•frequency of exposure

•comfort of the user

•communication needs

•medical conditions

•suitability to be used with other PPE

Click on the PLUS buttons to learn more.

Apart from that, you must also choose the correct PHP based on its Noise Reduction Rating or NRR listed on the packaging.

NRR is an average noise reduction in a laboratory test.

It is measured in Decibels (dB) where the higher the number, the greater the protection.

NRR only reflects noise reduction for a perfect fitting of PHP.

In the workplace, most people get much less protection because:

•PHP is not worn perfectly

•PHP is not worn during all noise exposures

You may refer to the Noise Risk Assessor or Hearing Conservation Administrator to determine the effectiveness of PHP to reduce noise exposure based on its assigned NRR and noise level at the workplace.

First, make sure your hands and earplugs are clean and dry. This is to avoid infection in your ear canal.

Then, roll the plugs between thumb and forefinger until completely compressed.

With the opposite hand, pull your outer ear upward and back, then insert the plug as far into your ear as possible.

Hold your finger against plug until it starts to expand.

Switch your hand to insert another plug into the other ear by repeating the same steps.

Proper fitting of earplugs into your ear is crucial.

A poor fitting will result in unnecessary exposure to noise and this is a common mistake made by employees.

A good fitting of earplugs should enclose tightly and firmly inside your ear canal. This will decrease noise exposure and protect you from ear damage.

Please take note that the correct procedure for fitting other types of PHP may vary. Kindly refer to the manufacturer’s instruction for further details.

All PHPs require a proper maintenance and disposal programme.

Frequent inspection of PHP is required to ensure of its condition.

The following are the general guidelines for maintenance and disposal of earplugs and earmuffs.

Click on the PLUS button to see the example.

OK, let’s have another Refresher before you proceed to the next lesson.

Do you still remember the Hierarchy of Noise Control?

Let’s try to complete this hierarchy by dragging the Noise Controls into the hierarchy according to their effectiveness.

Then, click SUBMIT to reveal the answer.

Let’s learn about Audiometric Testing.

Audiometric Testing is a test to determine your hearing sensitivity. It is a useful test in the Hearing Conservation Programme. From this test, you can identify if your hearing is compromised.

All employees who are exposed to noise exceeding the limits, based on the Noise Risk Assessment report are required to go through this testing.

They should go for testing within 3 months after commencing work as a baseline or reference for the next testing.

They are also required to go for annual testing.

The testing should be conducted after at least 14 hours period of quiet without the aid of a Personal Hearing Protector.

The test must be done by an approved Audiometric Testing Centre (ATC).

This is what happens during the Audiometric Testing.

First, you are required to sit in the testing booth, put on the headset and hold on to the signal switch.

Next, the audiometric technician will trigger a varying tone and frequency level in one of your ears.

When you hear a tone, press on the signal switch.

The technician will repeat these steps for the other ear.

Note that, you should not try to anticipate or intentionally miss a tone. This will lead to an inaccurate test.

If you are distracted or can hear noise from outside, please inform the technician to stop and repeat the test.

At the end of the testing, you will get an Audiometric Test Report.

State of hearing and degree of hearing loss from an audiometric test result can be determined from the diagram.

Click the PLAY button to listen to the sample sound demonstrating what one hears at a different state of hearing.

What should we do if our test result is abnormal?

We need to undergo a medical examination by an Occupational Health Doctor (OHD).

Upon advice by the OHD, we may have a follow up examination with an Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) specialist or other specialist.

We need to use proper PHP at all times during working in a noisy area.

We also need to avoid high noise when off work.

We have come to the end of the Noise & Hearing Conservation Awareness eLearning. Here is the recap of the module.

Click on the QUIZ button to test your understanding.

Good luck!
